review_title: Good benefits and good colleagues; University-wide confusion about mission & values
job_title: Instructional Designer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Salary is low but tempered by very good benefits; My colleagues are supportive and collegial
cons: Faculty and staff are confused about the ever-changing vision and mission of the university as provided from President Fike and Provost White. It's hard to relate to and defend a vision/mission that changes every term. Internal promotion is not equitable - promotions to leadership team have been hand selected by upper management.

review_title: The best people in the Bay

job_title: Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: GGU has a great working atmosphere and everyone is really helpful. The job can be boring sometimes, but there is a lot of meaning in the work that is done there.
cons: Salary isn't the best, but expected for a part-time/student assistant position.

job_title: Operations Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good place, opportunity to serve, and interesting architecture.
cons: Workflow is often not reflected in salary and lack of annual raises provided.

job_title: Professor in San Francisco, CA
pros: GGU has been in existence since 1901 and has a compelling mission of providing law and business degrees to open those professions to people who have historically been excluded. Students are great. I work with a lot of hard-working and committed people.
cons:
The current President is not an effective leader, in my opinion. Although he claims to be data-driven, he shies away from making decisions that the dedicated faculty and staff recommend based on their experience and knowledge. He has restructured senior leadership multiple times in his 6 years at GGU and can't seem to retain effective leaders. Probably because he does not provide them with the resources they need to accomplish crucial goals. He seems more concerned with creating a perception that he is achieving something. He seems to have tanked his prior institution and I only hope that the trustees quickly make a change. 
The lack of even cost of living raises for multiple years is demoralizing.

review_title: Steady Employment, Little-to-no Career Progression or Advancement
job_title: Operations Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
•Tuition Remission Benefit

•Commuter Reimbursement Program (Pre-Tax Dollars)
cons:

job_title: Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA

review_title: GGU's outlook is not looking good

Place is small enough to develop relationships

review_title: Some good benefits– but not enough to compensate for lackluster and stagnant pay
job_title: Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits: health insurance, life insurance, tuition remission for educational advancement
cons: 403(b) retirement plan match cancelled due to COVID with no word on when or if it will come back. pay is absolutely lackluster and stagnant, and is way behind the industry. They try to say, "But we offer great benefits," but in no way does that compensate for what the pay is, especially as they continue to cut back to adjust to COVID.

job_title: ELearning Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good culture, great people to work with

job_title: Events and Online Marketing Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: The benefits and flexibility are great!
cons: There is a small staff, and lots to accomplish.

job_title: Assistant Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: I had the chance to work with a great team; but not all the departments have good teams and managers. I was fortunate to have it.
cons: Not budget for employee development.

review_title: Good luck paying your mortgage or supporting a family
job_title: Assistant Director of International Admissions and Advising in San Francisco, CA
pros: Nice people, faculty and staff are friendly, helpful and diverse. Very little micro-management and because they are not a for profit institution, GGU does not run their admissions like a puppy mill.  They strive for retention, not just getting the students in the door for money. They help pay for your education, too. Good place to work if you are young and single and live in the city (not that you will be able to afford to off their salary).
cons:
Little chance of advancement unless  your are one of the "new favorites".  The pay is horrible - especially for being a university that is in the heart of san francisco.  Many of the staff work hard to get their education their but when they finish, it is not rewarded.  For example, if you get your Masters degree, you will still be making a salary only around 45k if you are lucky.  Benefits are only ok.  When I worked there, to get BASIC Kaiser benefits, it was costing me over 500 a month.
Hours were horrible.  I didn't get off work until after 6:30 and if you have a commute, this is awful - especially if you have kids. I wouldn't get home to my little ones until almost 8pm.

job_title: Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good opportunities to learn about higher education
cons: Small tem and not many opportunities to grow

job_title: Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: Mid level management are wonderful.
cons: Higher ups are not as much

review_title: Some good with a LOT of bad.
job_title: Faculty Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: GGU School of Law has some talented and interesting professors, people who know their stuff.  A lot of people who have been with GGU for years, which can be good or bad. Some people easy to work with and collegial, others more high-strung and high maintenance.  Good employer match on the 403b plan.
cons:
I have never worked anywhere with a more dysfunctional and passive-aggressively hostile work environment.  Chain of command is structured so your alleged boss is not your actual supervisor, and his lieutenant is the front line taskmaster.  They assign too many professors per assistant, making it impossible to keep up with all of their divergent needs.  Unreasonable and unrealistic demands, no ability to undergo constructive dialogue to resolve issues - a "my way or the highway" attitude.  

Weird thing is, since GGU employees are unionized, firing is almost impossible, so the way they try to get rid of employees they don't like is to use this middle manager to micromanage people to death so they willingly jump ship.  GGU was literally the only place I've ever worked where I received consistently negative feedback from a supervisor.  Every job I've held prior to or since has given me highly positive performance reviews.  

Bottom line; it's not me, it's YOU, GGU.

job_title: Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: all was good, great experience..
cons: none to be noted so far

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Easy Going
No Stress
Nice people
Good Location
Safe Job
cons:
Limited Growth
No Enough Work
Slow paced

review_title: The New President Has His Work Cut Out for Him
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Convenient location for commuting by public public transit . You'll feel a sense of purpose and that you are among people who care about the students they serve.  A new president took office which has many people more hopeful than they were a year ago,
cons:
Notice how GGU's earlier reviews were for the most part positive, but in 2013 they switched to being very negative and even somewhat hostile toward the university’s leadership. Clearly, something has gone wrong and it's driving down morale and increasing turnover.  

Accepting an offer from GGU at this moment in time means you are also accepting a work environment that is somewhat toxic.  Consider your ability to rise above it and persevere until, or if, the situation improves. 

Sustaining GGU in its current form will become impossible if it experiences one more year of enrollment decreases similar to the last two years.  The Board of Trustees may have to decide between slashing programs and services that will include layoffs, moving into a smaller footprint and selling the existing campus to a developer, seek a buyer and be acquired, or close.

review_title: Appreciated the experience but glad to move on...
job_title: Assistant Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: The people are kind. There is flexibility to get involved and start projects you care about. The students are great! And so is the location. Tuition remission and retirement benefits are good. I think the new President (David Fike) is taking things in the right direction, but there is a fair amount of damage to undo.
cons: Pay is very low and there were no raises or even cost of living increases during the multiple years I worked there. Lack of feeling appreciated / recognized, minimal opportunities for professional development - I stopped growing and feeling challenged. A lot of valuable people seem to get stuck and have no way of moving up.

review_title: GGU's administrative duties are unevenly distributed.
job_title: Disability Services Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Coworkers can be fun and supportive verbally.  My boss came to bat for me when needed (except financially) and tried to create a team environment.  Employees can take classes for free which is a great perk but make sure they offer classes in areas that interest you. The students can be fun to work with as can the professors although there is a large range of personalities.
cons: The physical structure is depressing and many of the work spaces are small with thin walls.  The work load is frequently not distributed evenly with employees who don't contribute going unnoticed and employees who work hard being over worked.  I was asked to work unreasonable hours and not appropriately compensated.  When I asked for a annual review in November, I still hadn't received one by August when I left.  Working with the law students, the pressure was intense as students were stressed and inclined towards being argumentative.

job_title: Assistant Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: GGU is a warm, hospitable, and supportive work environment. Employees are close knit, kind, friendly, and downright amazing. Most everyone is open hearted and quite humble. The staff is truly the glue keeping the university afloat...
cons: Golden Gate University used to be an innovative and competitive force on the market. Unfortunately they have fallen so far behind the pack that it is uncertain that they will make it to the finish line. Budgetary deficits are creating serious gaps within the infrastructure and increasing the work load exponentially for staff. Most individuals are doing the work of 2-4 people on a daily basis. Employees are dropping like flies as the management attempts to clean house and some of their best talent has abandoned ship. When you add the instability of the university along with the poor pay and expensive benefits you have the makings of disaster. Employees feel undervalued and overworked. Most are fielding job offers, applying for new jobs, updating their resumes, and attempting to find a life preserver should the boat go down.

review_title: Stay away from Law School Marketing
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: good retirement matching benefits, which is the main reason why people lay low for 20 years in the same position with low salary and no career growth.
cons: Worked in marketing for the law school. If you're not looking for an intense environment with negative politics and military abusive management style, please stay away.  95% of this job turned out to be in complete isolation, I was ready to kiss people's feet for stopping by.  My boss and I were the only two employees. I was not allowed to talk to anyone. I was indoctrinated that everybody in the entire building is bad and doesn't know how to do their job and expected to display full blind compliance with this and other paradigms. Some people left their positions because of the tension with my boss.  He has the Dean wrapped around his finger, her survival depends on him - nobody stands a chance.  Most people stay away and are intimidated. It's a very sad situation.  Morale is low.  Staff salary is low.  High turnover.  There is no culture, it's a stale, outdated environment.  Unfortunately, I cannot recommend. Females, please, please stay away from this particular marketing department.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: I like a lot of the people.  I have a supportive and caring supervisor who is hardworking and passionate.  My coworkers are great and care a lot.
cons: People are dropping like flies.  Everyone is leaving and if they haven't left, they're looking...I am.  HR is lazy and lack HR degrees.  They don't grant any exceptions for tuition being taxable and because tuition is so high, those taxes can financially break an employee.  I came from another university and with my title increase came a pay cut including increased commuting costs.  Lack of benefits, low pay, low employee morale, struggling IT department (which affects us all), failure of administration to acknowledge low morale and feedback.

job_title: Assistant Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: Friendly coworkers, easy assignments, close to BART, tuition remission, good for Yes People
cons: Low pay, no raises, no opportunities for growth, bewildering benefits, take-it-or-leave-it attitude especially from HR

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Commute is easy when taking the ferry. With the restructuring of the HR department I have learned a lot and have been provided with a lot of new skills.
cons: Not really a con but with the restructuring of HR as a part time employee I recieved a lot of responsibilities. I had to do a lot of trouble shooting, collaborating with other employees, and  figuring things out. I have gained a lot of useful skills and I am honored to receive the experience and opportunity to build my HR skills.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: You get to work in downtown SF, within proximity to all of the amenities it provides. Staff in nearly all departments are friendly and easy to get along with. If you pass on their health coverage they give the amount they would have put toward your health coverage. The work week is 37.5 hours. People leave at 5 p.m. They are very flexible. Very generous retirement match program.
cons: Pay is below standard for what is needed to live in SF. The health coverage is poor when compared to other universities. Little to no opportunities for promotion. Hard to retain quality talent

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great people to work with. Benefits are probably not the best but still are good. Also, as an employee you get tuition benefits.
cons: Salaries are low compare to other institutions. If you are thinking to advance in your career than definitely this is not a place for you as they almost never promote from within. Be careful as you get older because you will be the first on the list to get laid off if there will be restructuring.

job_title: Online Writing Tutor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Management for online tutors was very attentive and caring to its employees. Our mgr. tried hard to keep us all employed and busy. Wages were not terribly competitive, but they were decent, and we were always paid on time. Because we lived far from campus, we rarely saw ea. other face to face, but would get together at least once a year. We were provided plenty of guidance in our tutoring activities, and the mgr. solicited input from tutors for improving our standards and the students' writing.
cons: The system for entering work times seemed unnecessarily complicated.

review_title: Golden Gate University is a good place to work to get into the Education field - a stepping stone.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Employee relationships are some of the best. They are truly like family. When collaborating on projects or just on regular tasks and other departments, for the most part, people work very well together. They can be flexible with your schedule when needed; flexible in general.
cons: In the past four or five years until present, senior management and and other leaders have changed which is not uncommon when you get a new president as it has happened here in the past. This time around I am not sure what the agenda and mission is because senior management can't seem to get on the same page, and they don't collaborate with people in the trenches doing the work when they implement new software, reorganize departments and positions, etc. As a result, new systems make our jobs impossible to do because there certain pieces missing so we end up doing more manual work and double processing things. If they had worked with the people in the trenches and not just relied on what they thought was best because it worked well somewhere else they worked, then admissions and enrollment would definitely increase. That's what they want to happen, but they are not making the necessary decisions and collaborations to do so, so they will continue to go around in a circle. It used to be an awesome place to work. Now, it's fine. Definitely a good place to start and get more education.

job_title: Associate Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you are looking for a place to work where you won't be pushed too hard and it is a slower paced environment this is perfect.  Also, if you are a self-starter and don't need to be micromanaged at all, you will do well here.
cons: Department work in silos and it is run in a very top-down management style.  Also, there is no real room for career growth.  You can stay in the same position for decades without any promotion.

job_title: Circulation Student Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: The best thing about working at the Library while doing my Masters full time is to have flexible schedule and to be able to have some time to study at work. Also, as an international student, it gave the opportunity to have some experience in a U.S. environment.
cons: As an International student I am allowed to work 20 hours a week and usually they don't schedule us that many hours. 14-15 hours a week average.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Berkeley, CA
pros: New Dean in the last few years for law and business schools. Org seems open to change.  People are largely very very friendly and the students are earnest and likable.  Although not a household name they have been around 100 years downtown. Non profit. Neither snooty nor cheesy in culture. Located near Montgomery BART a plus.
cons: Some of the downsides of nonprofit orgs.

job_title: Data Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: No micro managing everyone treated as a professional excellent technology services open minded progressive president SOMA is a great area to work in
cons: Pay is below needed level to live in the Bay Area the pay should be realistic for how expensive it is to live in SFO and have regular raises included with job performance review

job_title: Associate Professor of Law in Orinda, CA
pros: People are pleasant and make an effort to be social.
cons: The facilities are an embarrassment: dark, cramped, with the feel of an archaic government building.  Compensation is a joke.  A few appear to be professional in appearance, but most seem to think this is a place for pajamas and lack of bathing.  It is shocking to believe this is an academic organization focused upon the business community.
